name: Levetiracetam (Keppra)
summary: An anticonvulsant used off-label in psychiatry for mood stabilization and behavioral control.
description: Levetiracetam is an anticonvulsant that binds to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), modulating neurotransmitter release and reducing neuronal excitability. It is FDA-approved for seizure disorders but has been used off-label in psychiatry for mood stabilization, aggression, and behavioral dysregulation, particularly in neurological conditions.

sections.text: Binds to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), reducing neurotransmitter release and stabilizing neuronal activity.

adult.seizures: Start 500 mg twice daily, increase by 500 mg twice daily every 2 weeks to max 1500 mg twice daily
adult.psychiatric_off_label: Commonly 500–1500 mg twice daily; titration individualized

sections.pediatric: 10 mg/kg twice daily, titrated up to 30 mg/kg twice daily
sections.geriatric: Same as adult; adjust for renal function
sections.hepatic_impairment: No adjustment unless severe, then adjust for renal clearance
sections.renal_impairment: Dose adjustment required based on creatinine clearance

sections.text: Onset within days; steady state achieved after 2 days of twice-daily dosing.

other: Monitor for behavioral changes including aggression and irritability
Avoid abrupt discontinuation to reduce risk of seizure recurrence

sections.pregnancy: Limited data; use if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant for sedation
sections.pediatrics: Approved for seizure disorders from 1 month of age

sections.text: Taper gradually over at least 1 week to avoid rebound seizures.

items: Generally well tolerated, but can cause significant behavioral side effects in some patients
No significant hepatic metabolism—few drug-drug interactions
